definitions: show something you have in an obvious way to attract attention or admiration
examples: She flaunted her expensive jewelry at every party
The peacock flaunted its beautiful feathers to attract mates

definitions: give a particular taste to food or drink by adding spices herbs or other ingredients
examples: The chef flavoured the soup with fresh basil and garlic
She flavoured her coffee with vanilla syrup every morning

definitions: remove the skin from an animal or person especially by cutting or tearing
criticize someone severely and mercilessly about their actions or behavior
examples: The hunter flayed the deer to prepare its hide
Ancient warriors would flay their enemies as punishment
The critic flayed the movie for its poor acting
The boss flayed the team for missing the deadline

definitions: mark or dot something with small patches or spots of color or particles
examples: Gray hair flecked his dark beard making him look distinguished
Paint flecked the artist's clothes after a day of work

definitions: develop wing feathers that are large enough for flight as a young bird grows
examples: The baby eagles will fledge in about twelve weeks
Most songbirds fledge within two weeks of hatching

definitions: obtain money from someone by deceiving them or charging them too much
examples: The dishonest mechanic fleeced customers with unnecessary repairs
Tourists often get fleeced by overpriced souvenir shops

definitions: bend a joint or muscle to demonstrate strength or prepare for physical activity
examples: He flexed his biceps in front of the mirror
Athletes flex their muscles before starting the race

definitions: move or cause to move with a sudden sharp movement typically using fingers
examples: She flicked the light switch to turn on the lamp
He flicked a piece of lint off his jacket

definitions: burn or shine with an unsteady light that goes on and off quickly
examples: The candle flickered in the wind from the open window
The old television screen flickered before finally going dark

definitions: throw or move something suddenly or forcefully in a specified direction
examples: She flung her bag onto the couch after work
The child flung the toy across the room in anger

definitions: behave in a playful way that shows romantic or sexual interest in someone
examples: She liked to flirt with the waiter at her favorite restaurant
He would flirt by making jokes and maintaining eye contact

definitions: move or gather together in large numbers like birds or sheep typically
examples: Tourists flock to the beach during summer vacation months
Fans flocked to the stadium for the championship game

definitions: fall move or hang in a heavy loose and ungainly way
fail completely in achieving intended success especially in entertainment or business
examples: He flopped onto the couch after his long day
The fish flopped around on the deck of the boat
The expensive movie flopped at the box office
Her new restaurant flopped within just three months

definitions: struggle or stagger helplessly or clumsily in water mud or when trying to move
examples: The swimmer floundered in the deep water without a life jacket
She floundered through her presentation without proper preparation

definitions: grow or develop in a healthy or vigorous way especially in suitable conditions
make a bold sweeping gesture or movement typically to attract attention
examples: The plants flourished in the greenhouse during winter months
Her business flourished after she found the right location
The magician flourished his cape before performing the trick
She flourished the letter triumphantly above her head

definitions: rise and fall irregularly in number amount quality or value over time
examples: Gas prices fluctuate based on supply and demand factors
Her weight tends to fluctuate between summer and winter

definitions: make something appear larger softer or fuller by shaking or patting it
examples: She fluffed the pillows before the guests arrived
The bird fluffed its feathers to stay warm

definitions: move quickly in a confused or agitated way often in groups
examples: Workers flurried around preparing for the important visitor
Leaves flurried in the wind during the autumn storm

definitions: clean something by causing large amounts of water to flow through it
become red in the face from embarrassment anger or heat
examples: Remember to flush the toilet after using the bathroom
The plumber flushed the pipes to remove the blockage
She flushed with embarrassment when everyone stared at her
His face flushed red when he realized his mistake

definitions: make grooves or furrows in a surface especially for decoration or function
examples: The baker fluted the edges of the pie crust
The carpenter fluted the wooden column for the building

definitions: fly unsteadily or rapidly by flapping wings quickly and lightly
examples: Butterflies fluttered around the colorful garden flowers
The flag fluttered in the gentle morning breeze

definitions: flow or cause to flow freely as a liquid in continuous change
examples: Energy constantly fluxes through the electrical system
The river fluxes with seasonal rainfall patterns

definitions: give birth to a baby horse donkey or related animal
examples: The mare will foal sometime in early spring
Wild horses typically foal during warmer months

definitions: form or produce a mass of small bubbles or froth
examples: The waves foamed as they crashed against the rocks
The beer foamed when poured too quickly into the glass

definitions: deceive someone into accepting something inferior or unwanted instead of what they want
examples: The dealer tried to fob inferior goods onto unsuspecting customers
Don't let them fob you off with excuses

definitions: cover or become covered with steam mist or condensation
make something confused unclear or difficult to understand
examples: The bathroom mirror fogged up during the hot shower
Her breath fogged the cold window on winter morning
Complex legal language often fogs the real issues
Don't let emotions fog your judgment in this matter

definitions: prevent something from happening or someone from achieving their aim or plan
examples: Police foiled the bank robbery with quick action
Bad weather foiled our plans for a picnic

definitions: instigate or stir up unrest rebellion or undesirable sentiments or actions
examples: Agitators tried to foment rebellion among the workers
False rumors can foment panic in communities

definitions: add a note at the bottom of a page giving additional information
examples: The author footnoted every historical reference in the book
Remember to footnote all your sources in academic papers

definitions: search widely for food or provisions typically in nature or by hunting
examples: Bears forage for berries before winter hibernation
The soldiers had to forage for supplies in enemy territory

definitions: make a sudden attack or raid into enemy territory typically to obtain something
examples: The troops forayed into neighboring villages for supplies
Pirates would foray coastal towns for treasure and goods

definitions: cross a river or stream at a shallow place by wading or driving
examples: Pioneers had to ford many rivers on their journey west
The hikers forded the creek at its narrowest point

definitions: prepare someone in advance for danger or attack with weapons or knowledge
examples: The general forearmed his troops before the battle
Knowledge of their tactics will forearm us against deception

definitions: predict or estimate future events or trends especially weather or financial conditions
examples: Meteorologists forecast rain for the entire weekend
Economists forecast slower growth for next quarter

definitions: decide not to have or do something pleasant or valuable that you want
examples: She had to forego dessert to maintain her diet
Many students forego vacations to save money for tuition

definitions: make something the most prominent or important feature in a situation or discussion
examples: The report foregrounds environmental concerns over profit
The director foregrounds personal stories in her documentaries

definitions: be aware of something before it happens through wisdom or special knowledge
examples: No one could foresee the economic crisis that followed
Experienced managers foresee problems before they occur

definitions: be a warning or indication of a future event through hints or clues
examples: Dark clouds foreshadowed the approaching storm
Early symptoms can foreshadow serious health problems

definitions: prevent something from happening or someone from doing something by taking action first
examples: Quick negotiations forestalled a lengthy strike
She forestalled his objections by addressing them first

definitions: lose or be deprived of property or a right as a penalty for wrongdoing
examples: Players forfeit the game if they break major rules
He had to forfeit his deposit when he cancelled late

definitions: shape metal by heating and hammering it into desired forms
produce a fraudulent copy or imitation of a document or signature
examples: The blacksmith forged horseshoes in his workshop
Ancient warriors forged their own swords and armor
Criminals tried to forge passports to cross the border
Someone forged his signature on the check

definitions: choose to give up or do without something desirable or valuable
examples: Athletes often forgo social events to focus on training
She decided to forgo her salary increase this year

definitions: make something official valid or legitimate by completing necessary procedures or documentation
examples: They need to formalize their agreement with a written contract
The company will formalize the new policy next month

definitions: create or devise a plan strategy or system methodically after careful thought
examples: Scientists formulate hypotheses before conducting experiments
The committee will formulate new guidelines for safety

definitions: abandon or leave someone or something entirely especially when needed most
examples: He vowed never to forsake his family in hard times
She felt her friends had forsaken her after the scandal

definitions: strengthen a place or position with defensive works to protect against attack
examples: The army fortified the border with walls and watchtowers
They fortified the castle before the enemy arrived

definitions: make something dirty or polluted with harmful or offensive matter
commit an illegal action against an opponent in sports
examples: Oil spills foul the ocean and harm marine life
Factory waste fouled the river for miles downstream
The player fouled his opponent with an illegal tackle
Basketball players foul out after six personal fouls

definitions: deceive or trick someone in a clever or cunning way
examples: The puzzle completely foxed even the smartest students
Don't let his friendly manner fox you into trusting him

definitions: perform a ballroom dance in pairs with a combination of slow and quick steps
examples: The couple learned to foxtrot for their wedding reception
Grandparents still foxtrot at the senior center dances
